awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: The Mechanics of Turbulence and Sediment Transport: Physically-Based Numerical Modeling of Flow, Sediment and Bed Evolution in the Bedrock Canyons
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Laura V. Alvarez has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the University of Oklahoma and Simon Fraser University. The proposed work will make substantial contributions to our capability to numerically understand and predict the physical phenomena that control sediment transport and morphodynamic evolution of river networks. Gains in the knowledge of the role played by macro-turbulence events in sediment dynamics will allow us to obtain a deeper understanding of what determines the geomorphologic changes and will lead to the development of more efficient models.This model can also serve to investigate to what extent information obtained from well-controlled experiments and numerical simulations conducted at laboratory scale can be used to understand the physics of sediment transport at larger scales and to provide predictions about river network changes. The fellow will engage education and outreach by developing a six-week summer course in fluvial modeling, integrating many of the proposed research experiments.

Eddy resolving three-dimensional simulations combined with field and laboratory observations allow elucidation of key elements of fluid dynamics and sediment transport in fluvial environments. These models can resolve the time-dependent, energetically important, turbulent structures of the flow capturing the interactions between these eddies and the loose bed boundaries where sediment entrainment and deposition can occur. This research study proposes a compelling strategy for applying state-of-the-art computational fluid mechanics to the study of sediment transport and morphodynamic processes in fluvial systems. The main objective of the proposed research is the development and testing of a fully three-dimensional turbulence resolving model using Dettached Eddy Simulation techniques that can simulate turbulent flows under a broad range of spatial and temporal scales and their effect on sediment transport, entrainment and deposition and channel/river reach evolution. The numerical model will then be used to (1) understand the role played by the plunging flows, secondary flows and velocity inversions on sediment transport, entrainment and deposition in river reaches and (2) explain morphodynamic changes based on the dynamics of the macro-turbulence effects and velocity redistribution inside the river reach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Award ID 1806205: The Mechanics of Turbulence and Sediment Transport: Physically-Based Modeling of Flow, Sediment and Bed Evolution in Bedrock Canyons.

Summary

In this proposal, a multi-physics model capable of predicting sediment transport and bed evolution change, while resolving the energetically important eddies in the flow is developed and tested at field-scale. To the best of my knowledge, this model is one of the first field- scale eddy-resolving models, that implements a coupled an eddy resolving model and a sediment transport solver, based on Detached Eddy Simulation (DES) techniques, with a movable bed module to study large-scale rivers. Eddy-resolving models have proven predictive capabilities for simulating turbulence in convoluted river systems. During Summer 2021, I was focused on addressing grid independence tests to optimize the grid resolution by minimizing computational expenses, and uncertainty due to domain discretization. For instance, a grid convergence study based on the grid convergence index (GCI) could be tested to evaluate the grid resolution. In this method, the easiest way to start is by generating a grid (step 1) that is considered as the finest grid resolution with small time step. As the grid is redefined, numerical results of the model approach an asymptotic value similar to the true physical solution of the model equations because the spatial and temporal discretization errors asymptotically approach to zero. This GCI methodology needs to be explore critically in eddy-resolving models since eddy resolving models always reveal finer scale turbulence structures with a finer grid, and therefore it is possible to incur in under-sampling at lower spatial scales. Note: I have been holding a position as an Assistant Professor at University of Texas at El Paso since September 1st, 2020. The results presented in this report corresponds to three months of work conducted during the Summer 2021 as part of a requested and approved no-cost extension of this EAR-PF.

2 Evaluation of Grid Independence Studies for Eddy-Resolving Models using Detached Eddy Simulation at the field-and-laboratory scales applied to Canyon River Systems.

2.1 Activities

Objectives and Methodology

The principal objective in this research is to contribute to the study of eddy resolution models in complex environments and evaluate the sensitivity of field-scale models to the resolution of the computational domain to identify complex patterns of geophysical turbulence in hydraulic features of river systems. 

2.2 Grid Independence Studies

The finer the grid, the more fluid structures are resolved in LES models. Resolved turbulence stresses are required away from the walls such that anisotropic mass and momentum diffusivity is simulated within turbulent flow regions or in the majority of the flow depth within the computational domain. The grid convergence technique proposed in this study is based on the fundamental principle that the grid is redefined, numerical results of the model approach an asymptotic value similar to the true physical solution of the model equations because the spatial and temporal discretization errors asymptotically approach to zero.

2.3 Model Description

The numerical model was developed in OpenFOAM environment. Two incompressible fluids (air and water) are solved  using the Volume of Fluid Method for phase-exchange. An adaptive mesh topology tool, including adaptive re-meshing has been incorporated to study grid independence study and adaptive domain geometry redefinition of physical-based models.

2.4 Findings

In this study a simulation of the discharge of an effluent into the ocean is employed to investigate the refinement of the grid only when the process are dominant. The simulation shows the pollutant concentration using a Triangulated Irregular Network (TIN) computational domain, where the mesh has been redefined at the inlet of the pollutant (Figure 1). These result showed our first steps toward finding a physics-based representation of processes that is based on an adaptive computational domain, aiming to correctly resolve the turbulence and advection/diffusion processes manifested at multiple time and spatial scales in complex flow environments. In the future, we aim to provide a framework to re-mesh the computational domain to resolve finer scale turbulent structures and advection and diffusion of particles, only where these processes become more relevant within the computational domain.

3. Broader Impacts

I am working on outreach and education at all levers from K-12 to adult education using art paintings of rivers of the world a learning environment. I am organizing art exhibits in local museums and mobile science education organizations, such as Insights El Paso organization (www.insightselpaso.org) and One Water (Somos Agua). The first exhibits is schedule for March 2022 in an event organized by One Water. This is a pilot project conducted in collaboration with an independent Colombian artist, Mr. Anibal Moreno, that painted all the oil canvas. Figure 2 shows the art collection of oil paintings (1 m x 0.6 m dimensions) that will be exhibited.
